I haven't studied much biology, so could someone guide me on this point?
We=
 usually make ANNs with neurons that take the weighted some of all inputs, =
apply a function, and give the same result to all its outputs.
Is this the =
case in nature as well? Is it that simple? or does the result vary across d=
ifferent outputs? and does it vary drastically?

If i've started asking que=
stions outside the scope of this discussion group, plz let me know :)

Rega=
rds,
Umer..

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Colin Green 
  To: nea=
t@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, June 03, 2004 3:49 AM
  Subject: Re: [=
neat] Re: Connections


  Hi Umer,

  I agree with John that multiple conne=
ctions between two given neurons 
  would be redundant. You can still repre=
sent the full range of values AND 
  reduce precision at the same time. Thi=
s is sort of what is already done 
  in Kens NEAT by the using the weight m=
utation exponent (I think that's 
  what it's called). This effectively def=
ines the size of weight 
  modifications, a larger weight mutation value gi=
ves you less possible 
  values between the minimum and maximum weight, hen=
ce reducing the search 
  space. I might be wrong on this one with reagrds =
to Ken's NEAT, but the 
  idea stands - if you only allow a limited set of =
values for connection 
  weights you limit the search space. You wouldn't w=
ant to limit it too 
  much, otherwise you might not be able to fully explo=
re the important 
  areas of, say, the sigmoid activation function.

  Coli=
n

  Umer Iqbal wrote:

  > Since, natural neural networks work good enough=
 :), couldn't 
  > decreasing our precision and allowing multiple connectio=
ns be a better 
  > way of making ANNs?
  > I dont have any idea how this m=
ight be achieved.. but I believe that 
  > the simpler we keep our domain a=
nd smaller our search space, the 
  > easier it would be to come up with so=
lutions..
  > If we could give higher probability of changing weights than =
adding 
  > new connections, we would in effect be searching in a concentra=
ted 
  > part of the search-space first before moving to higher levels..
  =
> That brings me to another idea that I once had: Shouldn't we decrease 
  =
> the precision of our weights?
  > Since searching in let's say 15 digits =
after decimal would be many 
  > times more difficult than searching in 8-1=
0 digits after decimal.
  > And the results would not differ much.
  > What=
 do the others say?
  > Can we achieve this somehow?
  >  
  > Umer..
  >  =

  >
